title: NSW to ban 'hateful' symbols, comments | ABC NEWS
description: NSW Premier Chris Minns has announced a raft of measures to 'clamp down on hate speech'.  These laws will give police greater powers to remove face coverings during public assemblies and outlaw terrorist symbols such as ISIS flags.    He also signalled his support of calls for a royal commission into the Bondi terror attack.  Mr Minns said there needed to be a "comprehensive" look at Sundayâ€™s mass shooting, which killed 15 people.  "Until we have a full and accurate picture of exactly how this happened, with a plan to ensure that it doesn't happen again, then I don't have answers to the people of New South Wales about what happened on Sunday," he said. title: NSW Premier calls for Royal Commission and bolsters hate speech laws | ABC NEWS
description: New South Wales Premier Chris Minns has supported calls for a Royal Commission to investigate the Bondi Beach terror attack that killed 15 people. title: Grace Tame and team launch campaignÂ against child abuse loophole | ABC NEWS
description: A national campaign is being launched to close a legislative loophole that prevents victim-survivors of child sexual abuse from seeking justice. Grace Tame is partnering with a man who tried to sue the Diocese of Ballarat for the abuse committed by Father Bryan Coffey, a known paedophile who died in 2013. The High Court ruled that the Diocese was not liable since the priest was not an employee. title: Bill Clinton, Mick Jagger and Richard BransonÂ pictured in Epstein files partial release | ABC NEWS
description: The US Department of Justice has released some documents from its investigation into sex offender Jeffrey Epstein and co-conspirator Ghislaine Maxwell. The release includes images of former US president Bill Clinton, as well as celebrities like Mick Jagger, Richard Branson, Kevin Spacey, and Bill Gates. These photos do not imply any wrongdoing. Many documents and images are heavily redacted.
